newsitem.title: USA: ZINC--U.S. demand motors along, eyes auto talks.
newsitem.headline: ZINC--U.S. demand motors along, eyes auto talks.

text.p: Healthy demand for zinc metal and firm premiums look set to continue into the fall, but much will depend on whether a key market - the auto industry - escapes a strike, traders and producers said.

"Demand is running out of control," said Martin Pede, sales manager at Canadian zinc producer Noranda Inc. "We are seeing incredible tightness in the market place and everyone calling for contract maximums."
"The only problem we have is trying to keep the pipeline filled - it's a good problem to have," Pede said. Production plants were operating flat out with no problems.
Zinc premiums have risen to 5.5 to 6.0 cents per pound over LME cash, up from 4.75 to 5.25 in late July.
"Consumers are not worried about premiums if the final price is still historically low. LME is under $1,000 per tonne so it's a bargain," a U.S.-based producer agent said.
LME zinc cash settled at $997 a tonne (45 cents/lb) on Thursday. Merrill Lynch forecast an average zinc price of 47 cents/lb this year and 53 cents in 1997.

"The bottom line has not changed in the last six months," a trader said. "But the market is tight and will remain tight in the near term. There is material coming in from Europe, it's just a question of how much."
Premiums were still barely enough to import metal from Europe, though good freight rates would tip the balance.
The market was closely watching the labor talks at the Big Three U.S. auto makers. The United Auto Workers union Thursday delayed a choice of strike target to give more time for talks.

"People still wonder about whether there will be an auto strike or not, which could change the picture quickly," Pede said. "Should there be no strike action then there would be nothing that would have the current market situation changed significantly."
Galvanized steel for auto bodies is a key market for zinc.

Meanwhile traders expected the U.S. Mint to enter the market mid-September for metal and may firm up premiums further. Higher LME zinc prices would, however, make premium hikes tougher to achieve, traders and producers agreed.

A North American zinc miner said the concentrate market was balanced, and a big surplus has not appeared. Treatment charges rose about $15 to $190 per tonne in 1996 because excess mining capacity was forecast.

"We do not expect major changes in treatment charges for next year," the miner said. "Despite LME inventory, producer and consumer inventory is tight to short. We expect the (metal) price to go higher in ensuing months."
Merrill Lynch said, "The absolute level of inventories remains relatively high at just over 1 million metric tonnes, equivalent to 8.7 weeks at current levels of consumption."
It is general felt in the industry that stocks must fall to six-to-seven weeks supply to sustain a rally.
The U.S. General Accounting Office has issued its draft report on stockpile zinc sales, but will not make the details public until industry reaction has been received and a final report issued.
"If the final report looks like the preliminary one, then I am in no hurry for it to come out," George Vary, the American Zinc Association's executive director, said.
